column4: I'm going nuts..trying to transfer some files from my old lappy that is pretty muched effed up...
I can't burn a dvd...and I can't get files onto either flash drive (error reading from file: input/output error)
is there any kind of quick fix to get around this?
Transfer across the network.
a few gigs shouldn't take very long to copy using a samba share.
unfortunately, I can't help with setting that up, because I'm here looking for help with that.
that depends on the machines involved, but that usually would take me at most 15 minutes.
what do you mean by "fix"?  What's wrong with it?
what filesystem is it?
if you're getting i/o errors from that drive, you need to check the filesystem for errors, and that's done differently on some filesystems
mount (with no args/options)

are you using a livecd?
also, do you have or can you make one?
can you make one
That what I'm trying to tell you!
without sudo working properly in your installed system, live-cd is the only reliable option.
it works like any other ubuntu installation.  plug in your external.  the old drive should be listed in your places menu.  You should be able to click it to automatically mount and open it
what type of filesystem is it?
stop the copying for now
it sounds like your disk is physically damaged.  if those files are important, you should consider taking it to a specialist.
probably.  the proplem seems to be the drive, so i wouldn't expect it to work for any destination.

if you're not willing to pay a specialist to recover the data, and it's not vital data, just copy in small chunks, shutting down after a minute of two to let it cool.  The drive will self-destruct if you keep using it, so if you do use it, only use it to very carefully back up the data
